audio_caption: The clip begins with suspenseful, dramatic orchestral music that sets an ominous mood. Then a male speaker starts, in a declarative, serious tone, referring to God's names in the Bible, and focusing on one special name to express God's eternal existence. The orchestral music fades out as the speech continues.

A male speaker discusses human limitations in understanding eternity, recalling a high school physics class where the concept of endless space overwhelmed him to tears due to mental strain. He mentions a teacher saying "space goes on for gazillions of miles". The speaker's tone suggests reflection and wonder.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing the concepts of space, time, and God. He speaks with a thoughtful tone, stating that space is "not forever," but God is eternal. He emphasizes the challenge of comprehending infinity and eternity. The speaker mentions that the holy name of God is "never pronounced as is as it is written".

The audio clip features a single male speaker with a formal tone discussing the pronunciation of God's name in religious contexts, explaining that "we don't pronounce God's holy four-letter name as it is written" and instead use the word "Adonai," meaning "the master."

A single male speaker begins by discussing an exception regarding a holy temple, quoting the Torah from Deuteronomy. He speaks in a measured, thoughtful tone, stating that God will "appoint a place for you to link his name there." He elaborates that this place allows one to express God's name, and that outside of it, the name is not generally pronounced as written.

The clip features a single male speaker with an informative and somewhat academic tone. He explains that the holy name of God was only pronounced in the holy temple of Jerusalem when the priests recited the priestly benediction from the Book of Numbers, and on Yom Kippur, when the high priest recited God's name ten times. He notes that, aside from these exceptions, the tetragrammaton is never pronounced as it is written. The audio also contains the sound of paper rustling.

The audio begins with a man speaking in a clear, didactic tone, explaining the context of using a special name of God. He describes how, outside prayer or reading the bible, this name is pronounced "Adonai". Then, he transitions to mention a more common term, "Hashem", which he translates as "the name," to refer to God. He transitions again to discussing other, potentially less holy names of God.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing names of God, explaining they are pronounced as written only during prayer or Torah readings. He mentions "Elohim" as an example, then states that otherwise, it's usually altered slightly, possibly to "Elokim." The speaker speaks in a calm and informative tone.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, delivering a monologue in an informative and somewhat formal tone. He discusses a reason why God's essential name is not pronounced, based on a verse from Exodus and explaining how the oral Torah interprets it. He mentions the concept of concealing God's name. He notes that the text of the Bible only has consonants, implying a written source for the quote. He mentions the Talmud as another source, and concludes that God commands that His name should be concealed.

A single male speaker elaborates on reasons for carefully pronouncing the names of God, not just the "special name of God, the tetragrammaton," referencing Deuteronomy chapter 28, verse 58: "You must fear this glorious and awesome name of God, your Lord." His speaking tone is informative and slightly formal. The speaker concludes that "we are supposed to treat God's name with tremendous awe and reverence."

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing "trepidation" and the third of the Ten Commandments, "You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain". He explains this verse's basic meaning and how rabbis teach it extends to all expressions of God's name, except as directed by God. The speaker is articulate and conveys a sense of solemnity.

The audio clip features a male speaker discussing the importance of respecting God's holy name. The speaker explains that just as we don't refer to our parents by their first names, according to Jewish law, we shouldn't use God's special name either, unless specified. The tone is calm and informative, emphasizing the significance of respect.

The audio clip features a single male speaker, using a measured and thoughtful tone. He discusses showing respect to God, explaining how it is not to be overly familiar with God's name. He notes that this special four-letter name of God describes his eternal essence beyond comprehension.

A male speaker begins by discussing the idea of evoking God's holiness by not pronouncing his name. He then discusses the prophets and their role in making God's name known throughout the world. The speaker asks rhetorically what it means to make God's name known, if not to recite it. His tone is serious and reflective.

The audio clip features a single male speaker in a serious tone discussing making God's name known. He specifies this as "publicizing to the world" who God is, that "God is the creator of absolutely everything in existence", and that God's "providence and supervision extends to everything that he created". He concludes that making God's name known is "to make his reality known to the world".

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the act of praising God's name. He explains this means being thankful, having gratitude, and extolling God for everything he does, emphasizing that it is a mandate in the Bible to always praise God and be thankful for His actions. Following this speech, the audio transitions into an instrumental piece with a somber and somewhat dramatic mood, with a prominent string section.
